fields.value: Indianapolis Fertility Study: Study of Social and Psychological Factors Affecting Fertility, 1941 (M086V1)

dsDescriptionValue.value:
From the original codebook:

Unlike other fertility studies which record fertility in terms of birth or pregnancy intervals, the Indianapolis study equated pregnancies and adoptions for the purposes of recording. This the fertility and contraception data contained on the tape are recorded in relation to "fertility events" and the periods between these events.

The couples interviewed in the Indianapolis Study were classified as either "fecund" or "sterile." These terms are defined in the Glossary on p. 705 of the documentation. "Sterile" couples were given a different set of questionnaires than those for "fecund" couples. Virtually all of the Indianapolis Study analysis was restricted to the "fecund" couples. Only the data for the "fecund" couples have been incorporated into this tape. (Refers to original tape format.)

The (original) tape consists of 4,275 variables. An additional 16 variables had to be deleted because the original data could not be reproduced in a meaningful way. The record length and blocksize are 4,667, and the number of cases is 1,444.

The Indianapolis Study is based on weighted data. Weighting was accomplished by duplicating the cards of selected individual cases. Accordingly, the 1,444 cases contained on the tape include a number of duplicates. A list of cases that were duplicated appears in the Appendix to the documentation.

publicationCitation.value:
Whelpton, P.K. and Clyde V. Kissler. Social and Psychological Factors Affecting Fertility. Volume I, 1946; Volume II, 1950; Volume III, 1952; Volume IV, 1954; and Volume V, 1958. New York: The Milbank memorial Fund.

Freedman, Ronald and P.K. Whelpton. 1950. "Fertility Planning and Fertility Rates by religious Interest and Denomination" in P.K. Whelpton and Clyde V. Kisslet (Eds.) Social and Psychological Factors Affecting Fertility, Volume II. New York: The Milbank Memorial Fund.

producerName.value: National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

fields.value: Structured. Example is present in documentation.

This dataset was originally stored on punched card and was reformatted to electronic format.  From the codebook documenting this process: "The Indianapolis Study is based on weighted data. Weighting was accomplished by duplicating the cards of selected individual cases.  Accordingly, the 1444 cases contained [in this current file] include a number of duplicates. A list of cases that were duplicated appears in the Appendix to the documentation."

From the codebook: "In order to eliminate inconsistencies among variables on the tapes and to conserve space, all summary measures have been excluded from the Indianapolis Study tape. For example, "total months of diaphragm use" has been omitted, because months of diaphragm use beofre and after the first pregnancy can be added to produce this total. No attempt was made to recreate a number of indices used in many of the analytic studies, since there was no documentation describing how these indices were created.  In a few instances the attitudinal variables contained in the tape are reversed in comparison to the published reports of the study.  In all such cases, we have assumed that the original documentation of the data was correct and some data were inadvertently reversed during the process of publishing the results. For the majority of variables, however, the data contained on the tapes are consistent with the published results.
